Bjarne Andersen wrote:
> Hi !
> 
> We are using the budget-facilities in heritrix with great success.
> However it seems that dns-requests are counted on the same queues as the URI's requiring those DNS-requests - thats quite OK
>   - but it seems that the DNS-requests use of the queue-budgets?
> We don't think they should since the budgets should count only request to those specific hosts not requests to DNS-servers ??
> 
> We use a DomainnameQueueAssignmentPolicy and when specifying a queue-budget of 500 we get only e.g. 470 objects from domains with lots of 
> hosts (e.g. 30 hosts) - because of the dns-requests using the budget.
> 
> best

It could be reasonable for DNS URIs to be 'free' with regard to the
queue-budgeting.

The reason they aren't now is that the budgeting process was
initially conceived as queue- and crawler-centric -- "how much
effort should the crawler expend in this direction?" -- rather
than concerned with the net impact on remote sites. (Retries
and other errors also deduct from the budget, so there's not
currently an iron relationship between budget and number of
URIs successfully retrieved.)

I've created an RFE to consider making DNS URIs costless (or
offer a costless option), with some other discussion of possible
changes:

   [ 1313341 ] Perhaps DNS URIs should be free?
   http://sourceforge.net/support/tracker.php?aid=1313341

In the meantime, I presume you're using a UnitCostAssignmentPolicy
to aim for a target number of retrievals; you could easily add your
own alternate NonDnsUnitCostAssignmentPolicy option which gives
DNS URIs a '0' cost and everything else '1'.

- Gordon
